content.description:
Pretty fun moves through undulating bulges, climbs like Boschido.

Somewhat distracting are the bolts of Boschido all the way up.

Surprisingly clean, maybe people have been TRing this off the Boschido  anchor.
content.protection: mostly in the finger size range, but there are a number of pods for larger cams, or hex's would work. Can use Boschido anchor or the anchor I added to Trad Death route or top out and rap off Crackmaster.
content.location: left side of Boschido column.

climbs.name: Whipsaw
climbs.fa: Kevin Pogue, Elisa Weinman Pogue, Jim Cunningham, Paul Hoornbeek

content.description: Nice narrow arete with bolts on the face to the left. Few loose blocks.
content.protection: 10 bolts to an anchor at top
content.location: to the right of "air guitar"

content.description:
Sorry about the name, not my choice.

This is a very worthwhile crack.

There are many crux's, be prepared for sustained pumpy moves.

I thought it was harder then Mr. Clean.

I pulled a fair amount of smaller loose rock off.

This route has been long ignored and dirty, so expect loose face holds as of 2017.

Have a lot of gear in the 1/4"- 1/2" range.
content.protection: mostly small cams, with occasional pod for bigger cams, lots of nut options. 2 bolt anchor, no chain at the top, rap off Mr. Clean.
content.location: between Crackmaster Lambada on the left and Mr. Clean on the right.

climbs.name: Vantage Point
climbs.fa: Kevin Pogue, Brian Bidduck, Paul Hoornbeek

content.description: Great sport route with a sweet view. Clips on the face to the right of the climb.
content.protection: 11 bolts to anchor with permadraw biners at top
content.location: Left of "Air Guitar", in between "Only the Lonely" and "Munging for Jesus"

content.description:
The name probably scares away most folks, but not me.

The book gives this a Â 10b R rating, maybe for the rotten rock near the start, be sure to get cam in slot below the choss,( only about 6' ) then right after it, rest of the route is pretty clean for a route never climbed. ( still loose rock to be expected )

I think this is 10a, we will see what the consensus vote is. It actually protects pretty well, and there are a number of good rests.
content.protection:
almost all .3-.5 camalot size with the occasional pod for bigger cams, nuts.

Bolted anchor with chain.
content.location:
Better Living on the left

Witholding Evidence on the right.

content.description:
Good choice for a warm up or the aspiring 5.9 leader.  13 bolts...just try not to Z clip.

Follow the juggy arete to a set of anchors. Popular.
content.protection: draws
content.location:
Between

Pony Keg

and

Corner Pockets

content.description:
Jam and stem up the left crack to a bolted anchor.

Good pro.
content.protection: Gear to 3.5
content.location:
Sunshine Wall (center) between Narlux and Peaceful

Warrior.

content.description:
This long route has some varied climbing and especially fun moves at the top arete.

Great lead for the aspiring 5.10 leader. Start up the broken corner of the arete into a large ledgy area, the up a short crack, and finally up to a nicely exposed pillar.
content.protection: 16 bolts and chain anchor
content.location: Two routes to the right of Mix it Up, immediately right of Hole in My Soul. This route marks the right-side boundary of King Pins. Routes further right are on Coyote Wall.

content.description: On the recommended routes list in the Yoder/Ford guidebook. Stem your way up between a dihedral and pillar, placing gear into the dihedral crack. There is a large chockstone at ~70 feet that has slings around it that used to serve as the end of the route--climb past this another 30 feet to the new bolted chain anchors.
content.protection: Standard rack, on the bigger size. The crack is fairly uniform at about #2 & #3 Camalots most of the way, widening to #4 in the top bit past the chockstone.
content.location: Between the two sport 5.9s Whipsaw and Throbbing Gristle.  If you continue to the top, walk a few routes to the East (climber's right) to an obvious rap station.

content.description: Awesome stemming route especially if you have long legs. The book claims anyone over 6' can drop a letter grade, make what you want of that. placing gear on the left seemed best to me. Hard part is seeing what you place. Eventually move left to a bolted anchor or top out.
content.protection: Bring many small tcu's and stoppers for the bottom, some hand-sized pieces for the top.

content.description:
Great sport climb on the outer face of the column that forms Seven Virgins and a Mule. I can't recall how many bolts it is, but nice sustained climbing with frequent rests on good holds gets you up to a big incut ledge.

Generally well bolted, at this point you'll be about 7-8 feet above your last bolt, with another just around the corner... but you've got a slightly hair raising stance to clip from! You'll need a steel pulse to get through it...

After that it's a quick romp to the chains.
content.protection: Bolts, can't recall how many but you can see them all from the ground.
content.location: On the outer face of the column whose inner face is part of the Seven Virgins and a Mule chimney.

content.description: An offwidth that doesn't really require offwidth moves.  Strenuous but protects really well.  One of the best 5.9's at the Coulee.
content.protection: A double set of cams to 3 inches, or a single set of cams and one of hexes.  Takes hexes really well.
content.location: Between Bob's Your Uncle and Mix It Up.

content.description:
Stems and Seeds little brother.

Not quite as classic as S&S, but every bit as fun. Scramble up to a belay from an upper pedastal at the base of the stem box. A tricky start will get you going and good rests will keep you going. You can get gear in both cracks but better to pick one and go with it (left).

Near the top, most people choose to exit on the right hand crack though you can continue straight up, either way watch for loose rock...

A bolt anchor exists at the top.
content.protection: up to 3"
content.location: Left of the bolted route Hakuna Matata. Look for an obvious stem box that starts about 20 feet above the trail.

content.description:
Start by face climbing up around a wide crack which widens to the point where you can get inside.

Once you are inside the crack there are lots of big holds to make this chimney very easy. There is also a crack that takes regular size gear.

Near the top the chimney widens and the rock becomes smoother and less eroded. Keep chimneying through this and exit to the left. (Towards the river)
content.protection: Gear to 3", include small nuts and cams if you want to sew it up, and a sling and draw for the chockstones. Rap off the second chockstone (3 slings/3 quicklinks) or the bolted (chain) anchor shared with Stroking the Chicken.
content.location: The large crack to the right and behind the freestanding pillar with Throbbing Gristle.

content.description:
What a unusual name for Bill. I have been considering this for a while ( no not the SWV )and took the time to battle the wind tunnel chimney and dive bombing pigeons to make a six point trad anchor and squirm through the squeeze chimney to climb this.

The face on either side of this is mostly smooth and clean. The crack is still pretty dirty.

Mostly hand and fists, some fingers and face holds. near the top it goes to OW/ Chimney and you have to move above the last gear while squeezing  in and then move out to right face and a finger crack.

This should get more stars when it is cleaned.
content.protection:
Full range of cams to 4". Optional #5. remember some smaller cams for the top out.

There was no anchor. So instead of squeezing through into pigeon poop and trying to find a trad anchor that won't kill you I added a anchor for rapping.
content.location: Peaceful Warrior on the left, George and Martha on the right.

content.description:
The fairly obvious chimney to the left of

George and Martha

and

Peaceful Warrior

. A crack in the chimney provides good protection and as chimneys go, its actually pretty fun. When its windy, it can be REALLY WINDY inside the chimney as the wind gets funnelled in from one side right into you. So bring a jacket.
content.protection:
Standard trad rack to 3".

Anchor is two bolts with chains

content.description:
Hand and fist crack that gets progressively wider as you go up until you have sections with larger pods that undulate as the columns come together. Where the columns come together takes some gear but gear becomes more spaced at the top. No anchor on top. We moved over to Code of the bolt warrior but the links on that anchor need to be replaced.

Quite a bit of dried pigeon poop at the top. This climb would be more popular and be cleaner if there was an anchor due to the moderate grade.
content.protection: Gear to #4, there are wide sections in the pods but then you are mostly placing gear where columns come together so back to regular rack.
content.location: The crack to the left of Crackmaster Lambada and to the right of Code of the bolt warrior.

content.description:
Red M&Ms is a great stemming route that heads up the corner just right of

George and Martha

. Any actual holds on the route are small and some stemming skill is a bit of a necessity.

The route starts with easier moves, and then gradually increasing in difficulty, with possibly the hardest move just below the anchor. Avoid using the wide crack on

George and Martha

.

This route started its life as a trad route, was bolted, and now chopped to make for an exercise in using thin pro. You can access the anchors from the routes on either side to set up a TR if you aren't comfortable on thin pro.
content.protection:
Many small nuts. Bolted anchor at the top that is shared with

George and Martha

.

content.description:
I was working on stuff at the Middle East wall and got too cold so had to find something in the sun. Being Monday I had the place mostly to myself and what better time to do some quarrying.

Theres a route under all this choss I am sure of it.

It looked promising it is just very loose.

It had a 5.8 rating in the book and gear up to #6, and chimney????

More like 5.9, gear up to #4

I have been up dozens of these Robbins FA's now and likely 2nd ascent. He always climbed these cracks ground up, no precleaning, infact they are never cleaned and the choss is horrifying. every single face hold comes off in your hands or under your feet. the sides of the crack have a layer of crumb cake that will not take pro. There are basketball sized holds that look solid and slip right off with the smooth basalt cracks. He survived all these crazy cracks to die in a avalanche.
content.protection: not sure yet, still too much rock falling off, crack size changing. no anchor, very convoluted trad anchor at top.
content.location: next crack to the right of Never forget your friends.

content.description:
Pony Keg ascends the fist/hand crack to the left of the Whipsaw arete, and is the first crack system right of

Air Guitar

.  Scramble to a rocky ledge about 15 feet above the trail and belay near a large boulder inscribed with a memorial to Goran Kropp.

Jam your way up Pony Keg also using incut holds in the crack and on the faces of the dihedral as you go.  The route begins with small hands and gets bigger as you ascend, ending with a section of wide fists. You can frequently stem to place gear and rest, but I still had a fair pump by the time I reached the anchor (shared with Whipsaw).
content.protection:
A handful of larger stoppers plus cams in the 1-4" range will suffice.  Leave the small stuff behind.  I took 2 #3s and a #3.5 and was happy to have them at the top when the crack got wide.  You might be comfortable with fewer big pieces, but running things out at Vantage is not the best idea and is particularly disconcerting on the routes near

Air Guitar

.

content.description:
This route is mostly good setting up a toprope for beginners or as an easy sport lead. It is the wide crack/corner to the left of

George and Martha

and there are bolts on the face next to it. Apparently if you don't go straight up the crack you can make it harder.
content.protection: Quickdraws, bolted anchor at the top.

content.description:
OK, people say the ratings at Vantage tend to be soft. This is rated 10d in the book and I hesitate to upgrade, but it is much harder than quite a few 11a's I have done at Vantage- maybe those should be downgraded.

Approach on the right side of broken column, chimney up to first bolt.

Crux between 4th and 6th bolt. I have tried both sides of column, a bit thinner on the left, more awkward on the right- with more gear options if you want from the crack. Being in the center on tiny crimps feels more like 11a.
content.protection:
9 bolts, cams for crack,  small cams up to 1-2"- perhaps the name implies this.

This now has a bolted sport clip anchor.
content.location: The column arete behind a short pillar and right of Mr. Clean- 11a finger crack.

content.description: Climb the balancy arete past seven bolts to an anchor.
content.protection: bolts, permadraw anchor
content.location: First route left of Tangled up in Blue.

climbs.name: Mr. Clean
climbs.fa: Peter Hunt, Bill Robins, and Pete Rieke 88'

content.description:
A good finger crack and stemming dihedral.

Climb a short section of choss to the top of a short broken pillar to the right of the belay.

Climb the corner dihedral in front of you. There is a bolted line on the face to the right of the corner. Finger locks and stems stay consistently interesting to the top. Belay from bolts on top (no rappel or lowering hangers).
content.protection: Mostly small with a couple hand-sized. Slings to avoid drag on first couple pieces.
content.location: Just right of Boshido (bolted 10.b) there is a alcove with 5 crack routes. Mr. Clean is the right-most corner above the broken pillar. Just left of the next bolted route (Friends 10.d).

content.description:
I think this is one of the better routes on the Sunshine Wall. Its got a bit o' everything.

Start out with excellent face climbing which is sustained and technical for the first 5 bolts.

Oh, but don't let your guard down now, time to start placing gear...

Continue up the crack on the right side of the pillar via finger locks and small hands until its possible to move left into a thin crack (small stoppers) near the top.

Top out and belay from the top. Rap off of Bob's your Uncle.
content.protection: single set up to 2" mostly finger sized.
content.location: Last route before the King Pins. Look for a line of 5 bolts that ends about 1/2 way up the face.

content.description: Can be done as one pitch or two. There is a two bolt anchor halfway up, on top of the large ledge, and another at the top. Moves are straightforward between standard Vantage incut holds on the first pillar, and increase in difficulty on the second half.
content.protection: 6 bolts to first anchor, 3 to second. First anchor has rap chains, second has lowering biners.
content.location: Near the beginning (climber's right) of King Pins. A well chalked six foot step leads to a ledge, then the bolts lead up the pillar. When you reach the top of the column (halfway up the wall) move to the next column to the right and follow the rest of the bolts.

content.description:
One route to the left of

Stems and Seeds

. Bolted arete climb, lots of bolts, all in all a fun climb. Lower off bolted anchor.
content.protection: 12 bolts. Permadraws at anchor.
content.location:
The arete between

Stems and Seeds

and Sinsemilla.

content.description:
This route is in the central/left part of the Stems and Seeds area. It is the 2nd crack to the right of the fairly obvious

Seven Virgins and a Mule

(5.7) chimney. An excellent handcrack with some faceholds that provide very nice stances for placing pro. It gets a little wide at the very top. This is the route to climb if you want to toprope

Red M&Ms

.
content.protection:
Standard trad rack, mostly in the handcrack size with one bigger piece for the top (3" is good). There is a bolted anchor at the top that is shared with

Red M&Ms

.

content.description:
This one is pretty exciting, with thin crack, thin crimps, tricky gear placements.

The only way this is 10c is if I stem off the column on the other side of the chimney, otherwise it seems like a 5.11.

I did some cleaning of this 1/22/2018.
content.protection:
Standard rack, many small cams and nuts.

I think of Vantage like people say about sandstone, place allot of gear, sometimes two together gives one confidence to move past a crux.

I added a anchor to this in Jan. 2018. No chain, the Narlux anchor is 3' away for rapping.
content.location: just right of the chimney- 7 virgins and left of Narlux.

content.description: Similar to 'Party in Your Pants', but shorter and less grovely.  Climb twin cracks, stemming easily between them with your choice for pro.
content.protection: A range of sizes with doubles of Camalots #.75 - #2.
content.location: Immediately left of Air Guitar

climbs.name: Crossing the Delaware With Your Pants Down

content.description: Thin, but positive moves lead up 7 bolts to a layback. Chain anchor at the top. Bring a blue or yellow sized TCU for the top part unless you want to run it out as the bolts stop a good ways below the anchor.
content.protection: 7 bolts to the anchor. Bring a yellow and/or blue TCU for the upper section unless you feel like running it out
content.location: Bolt line just to the right of Red M&M's

content.description: Great sustained trad route reminiscent of the Smith gorge. Spotting the right feet keeps the pump factor down.
content.protection: Gear to 2"
content.location: Inside corner between Mr. Clean and Boshido

content.description: Start on "Justified Ancients of Mu Mu" (5.8 bolts) or climb friable rock to the right up to the ledge and first set of anchors. Continue up the corner, left of the bolted arete.
content.protection:
Standard rack.

The anchor at top has two bolts and chain.
content.location:
Just right of

Throbbing Gristle

content.description:
This route deserves more then the 1 star it gets in the book. The PG rating also does not apply any more than the usual loose rock at Vantage. The PG rating is for the bottom broken ragged crack, the Corner Pocket crack or the bolted Ancients could be climbed to pillar top anchor, then step right.

The description of hand crack at the top does not prepare you for the burly fingers layback without the usual face holds.

Good to save #2 Camalot for top tight hands crack.
content.protection:
gear to 3", the lower half would take hex's well in the funky pods. save some #.4, #.5 #.75, #1 for the upper layback and #2 camalot for tight hands jam at top.

This route now has a 2 bolt chains anchor, 2/2/2020.
content.location: This is the inside corner 2nd crack right of Justified Ancients

content.description:
A seldom done route. Maybe the code of the bolt warrior is to sandbag the trad climber. This route is listed as a 5.9 and is way harder- about the same or harder than Crackmaster Lambada. Most routes at Vantage tend to overrated, with a few exceptions.

Don't attempt to climb this at the same time that someone is climbing Boschido, too much overlap with arete holds.

I gave this a major makeover 1/22/2018. Lots of small rock and dirt scraped out of the crack and a suitcase size rock came out. I added a anchor too. There is just no way this could be 5.9, there are sustained big 10b moves for much of the middle of the route. Most of the gear is in the 1/2" size, widens up some at the top.

When you are perched up on top looking down you can see that it is slightly overhanging.
content.protection:
Pro to 2-3".Very long, double rack with hex's useful for undulating constrictions, several pumpy crux moves .

You could easily place 4 each of .4 and .5 Camalots.

I added a anchor just below the top. The trad anchor options are pesky and there used to be bolts that were chopped.
content.location: next crack to the right of the long bolted route Boschido.

climbs.name: Clip 'em or Skip 'em
climbs.fa: Kevin Pogue, Elisa Weinman Pogue, Craig Dodson, Barbara Jones

content.description:
Great sport route - clips on the face to the right of the climb. Chunky, positive edges slowly get worse to a crux move near the top and an awkward final mantle move.

Chains are set pretty far back from the edge so careful with topropes, and make sure your ropes don't get stuck in the crack!
content.protection: 10 bolts to bolted anchor with mussy hooks.
content.location: To the left of "Air Guitar", to the right of "Vantage Point." The bolts are on the side that faces left, and it climbs the aretes just to the left of the bolts.

climbs.name: Climbing in the Temple of Doom

content.description:
I like Yoder's description:

Highly recommended for your worst enemies.

just needs some cleaning, avoid till done.
content.protection: standard full rack, no anchor
content.location:
Commeteme on Left

Catnip on Right

climbs.name: The Chossmaster
climbs.fa: Kevin Pogue, Elisa Weinman Pogue, Craig Dodson

content.description: Much better climb than the name implies. The 2 pitches can easily be linked with a 60 m rope.
content.protection: 14 bolts to an anchor at top
content.location: Leftmost climb on the King pins, just to the right of the tilted pillars.

content.description:
Not a bad crack, just really dirty. Mostly hands-wide hands.

I bailed off to Hakuna Matata anchor near that ledge, there was so much scary jumbles of loose rock.

As Yoder guide says would be good if it got more traffic. I keep meaning to get back since climbing this in 2009 to clean it, needs some crow bar action while nobody around.
content.protection: mostly hand sized.
content.location:
Sinsemilla on left

Brownie Power on right

Hakuna Matata next right.

content.description:
Another funky Vantage crack climb, but it is pretty interesting on the upper half. It is listed as 10c PG in the book, but I found it no harder to protect then the average Vantage crack.

Pretty sustained jamming without the usual face holds makes this pretty pumpy.
content.protection: gear to 3", shares anchor with Delaware over to the left. Hex's would work well in the ragged undulations of the lower half. The bulk of cams is medium size, .4, .5, .75.
content.location: next crack right of Delaware, and left of Only the Lonely- which is an OW and next right is Vantage Point with massive amount of bolts.

content.description: Fun finger crack that doesn't see much traffic despite being in such a popular location.  There is a minor technical crux but sustained gear placement is the major obstacle here.
content.protection: Gear to 3" with micro cams and stoppers. Protection is good but can be difficult to find.
content.location: First route belayers left of sinsemilla.

content.description:
adding this in hopes of later cleaning and so you know to avoid it till cleaned.I did some cleaning and climbed this including top out- which is a spectacular 10b finger crack. most of the lower crack is ho-hum.

the scary blocks just left of Hakuna Matata anchor ledge are still there and have chalk all over them.
content.protection: standard trad rack to 3", many finger size gear.
content.location: bail at top to Hakuna Matata anchor on the right, or top out using two small finger cracks, can use the Stems and seeds anchor with cordellete.

content.description: Tall arete/face climb up a typical vantage pillar. Sustained climbing outside the many good rests.
content.protection: Guide says 13 bolts but there's one more just below the anchor. Closely bolted for most of the route.
content.location: 2nd bolted route from the left in the area. Next to the chossmaster. Should be able to rap with a 60m rope or walk off climbers left to gully #2.

content.description:
If you like finger cracks, you're gonna love your Uncle Bob.

Standing on the trail you can easily spot the crux. Work your way up the finger and hand crack using great jams, crimps, underclings, jugs and stems until you arrive at the business.

It's short and sweet and will test your thin crack skills but the gear is good. Chains at the top.
content.protection: up to 2" with extra finger size.
content.location: Just left of offwidth (steel grill 5.9) and right of Stems and Seeds.

climbs.name: Better Living Through Superior Chemical Management

content.description:
Not the usual single crack all the way up, some crack switch with broken discontinuous thin cracks.

The crux is in the first 30 feet, where it is thin and hard to protect, seems just as hard as the 11a cracks at Vantage,it was 10c in the book but maybe it is 10d. Pink X4, C3's, blue and green Aliens.
content.protection:
mostly very small cams and nuts up to 3". You will want multiple .3 , .4 and .5 Camalot size. Brass nuts for start, if even that hardly works, maybe Ball-nuts, I did not try those. There are a few short run-outs up high where there are more jug holds, just look for pro, and save some small cams for some good horizontal cracks.

No anchor, can access Chossmaster anchor and or gear anchor. The gear anchor is a pain in the neck- use a cord-o-let.

I refrained from adding an anchor to this one, not really sure anyone will climb it.
content.location:
first crack right of the Chossmaster.

Trad. Death route on the right.

content.description:
Sometimes I avoid routes at Vantage because they just don't look good. Well this has a adventurous alpine feel if you want to do something crappy. You can even choose to climb all 3 cracks by doing a traverse to the right and finish on the 7 Virgins chimney anchor.

Much like other off width cracks at Vantage you can do mostly face climbing.

This would be better if cleaned.
content.protection:
Single rack to #5, or extra #4, #5. If you top out there is no anchor, and not great gear options.

There is a anchor on a pedestal above the chimney behind Steel Pulse.
content.location: This is in the middle of a little alcove between Steel Pulse on the right and Never Forget your Friends on the left. There is a 5.8 crack to the left of it that is a major pigeon condo to be avoided and another crack on the right before Steel Pulse.

content.description:
One of the Coulee's best hand cracks.

Jam thin hands to hands to fists with a spot o' offwidth below the anchor.

Bolted anchor
content.protection: tcu's and cams to 4", Permadraws at anchor
content.location:
Between

Pony Keg

and Crossing the Threshold

content.description: Continues up past the Mu Mu anchor through very bouldery compression moves until it eases up at about 20 feet. Doesn't feel much like a Vantage route since the rock is nearly flawless.
content.protection: Two bolts, and maybe finger size cam for the finish. Use Commeterme anchor off to right.
content.location: Continuation of Mu Mu, stay on the face past anchor.

content.description:
Starts at the crack to the right of Shady Chimney. Mostly hand holds at the beginning, up to a decent hand crack. You can stem on Shady Chimney at first crux.

End of the route has an interesting pair of finger cracks and large step blocks.
content.protection: You might be able to squeeze a BD #4 in there, but gear to 3" is fine
content.location: The crack opposite of Shady Chimney. Optional variation links up to Corner Pockets after the pillar.
